profileText: A Representative from Indiana; born in Uniontown, Perry County, Ind., April 9, 1793; moved with his parents to Clark County, Ind., in 1806; attended the public schools; fought in the Battle of Tippecanoe; appointed lieutenant in a company of United States Rangers, authorized by an act of Congress for defense of western frontiers, in 1812; brigadier general and major general of the Indiana Militia until his death; county clerk 1824-1830; presidential elector for Jackson and Calhoun in 1824; elected as a Jacksonian to the Twenty-second, Twenty-third, and Twenty-fourth Congresses (March 4, 1831-March 3, 1837); chairman, Committee on Private Land Claims (Twenty-fourth Congress); unsuccessful candidate in 1836 for reelection to the Twenty-fifth Congress; elected as a Democrat to the Twenty-sixth Congress (March 4, 1839-March 3, 1841); died in Charlestown, Clark County, Ind., January 20, 1845; interment in the Old Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the Carr Family Papers, 1829-1925, 2 boxes (also includes 1 oversize folder, and 1 box visual materials).
researchRecord.description: The collection contains the correspondence, documents, records, literary writings, and photographs of the Carr family. Letters of John Carr are from when he served in the U.S. House of Representatives, and include letters to his son, Andrew J. while a college student, and to other family members. A guide to the collection is available in the repository.
